frontmatter.title: Fortran - ARM 64-Bit Platform - Subtract Two Integers

children.value: In this section we will be disassembling simple binaries generated by the Fortran high-level language compiled for the 64-bit ARM platform.
Project code for this section is contained in my

program sub_int

    implicit none

    integer    :: a, b, c

    a = 5
    b = 3

    c = a - b

end program sub_int
The program displays the contents of the program
. The program creates three integers: a, b, and c.
is assigned the value of 3, and
is assigned the result of the operation
The program is obviously very simple, with no inputs and outputs. The idea is to generate the binary and look at the disassembly to learn about the workings of the 64-bit ARM processor platform.

The chosen test system is my trusty Samsung Chromebook Plus V2, which has a 64-bit ARMv8 processor. This is a very convenient platform for this exercise due to its availability and ease of access from multiple remote systems via SSH.
The program is compiled with the GNU Fortran compiler,
, which is available on the ARM platform. The program is compiled with debugging information using the
option, which allows us to debug the program in GDB and see the source code interspersed with the assembly instructions.
For general edification, we also have
option, an object file with the
option, and object dumps of the object and executable files.
The generic assembly is generated by using the
The object file is generated by using the
The objdump files are generated by using the following command and options:

$ objdump -x -D -S -s -g -t sub_int.o > objdump_of_dot_o.txt
$ objdump -x -D -S -s -g -t sub_int_Fortran_aarch64_ggdb3 > objdump_of_dot_exe.txt
A rundown of the objdump options is shown here:

$objdump 
Usage: objdump <option(s)> <file(s)>
 Display information from object <file(s)>.
 At least one of the following switches must be given:
  -a, --archive-headers    Display archive header information
  -f, --file-headers       Display the contents of the overall file header
  -p, --private-headers    Display object format specific file header contents
  -P, --private=OPT,OPT... Display object format specific contents
  -h, --[section-]headers  Display the contents of the section headers
  -x, --all-headers        Display the contents of all headers
  -d, --disassemble        Display assembler contents of executable sections
  -D, --disassemble-all    Display assembler contents of all sections
      --disassemble=<sym>  Display assembler contents from <sym>
  -S, --source             Intermix source code with disassembly
      --source-comment[=<txt>] Prefix lines of source code with <txt>
  -s, --full-contents      Display the full contents of all sections requested
  -g, --debugging          Display debug information in object file
  -e, --debugging-tags     Display debug information using ctags style
  -G, --stabs              Display (in raw form) any STABS info in the file
  -W, --dwarf[a/=abbrev, A/=addr, r/=aranges, c/=cu_index, L/=decodedline,
              f/=frames, F/=frames-interp, g/=gdb_index, i/=info, o/=loc,
              m/=macro, p/=pubnames, t/=pubtypes, R/=Ranges, l/=rawline,
              s/=str, O/=str-offsets, u/=trace_abbrev, T/=trace_aranges,
              U/=trace_info]
                           Display the contents of DWARF debug sections
  -Wk,--dwarf=links        Display the contents of sections that link to
                            separate debuginfo files
  -WK,--dwarf=follow-links
                           Follow links to separate debug info files (default)
  -WN,--dwarf=no-follow-links
                           Do not follow links to separate debug info files
  -L, --process-links      Display the contents of non-debug sections in
                            separate debuginfo files.  (Implies -WK)
      --ctf[=SECTION]      Display CTF info from SECTION, (default `.ctf')
      --sframe[=SECTION]   Display SFrame info from SECTION, (default '.sframe')
  -t, --syms               Display the contents of the symbol table(s)
  -T, --dynamic-syms       Display the contents of the dynamic symbol table
  -r, --reloc              Display the relocation entries in the file
  -R, --dynamic-reloc      Display the dynamic relocation entries in the file
  @<file>                  Read options from <file>
  -v, --version            Display this program's version number
  -i, --info               List object formats and architectures supported
  -H, --help               Display this information
We will now disassemble this program on the 64-bit ARM platform and step through the assembly instructions.
When we look at the executable’s objdump, we notice that there are two functions of interest, one is
. The Fortran compiler sets up the program arguments and options in
, while the actual program is contained within
(that is capital MAIN followed by two underscores).
The following text from the executable’s objdump illustrates this:
for a Fortran program that performs a
. We’ll break down the code into detailed steps and reconstruct the equivalent Fortran source.

program subtract_int
  implicit none
  integer :: a, b, c

  a = 5
  b = 3
  c = a - b
end program subtract_int
subroutine, which is generated for the Fortran program body.
This is the entry point for the Fortran program (not to be confused with the
function that wraps it for execution).
(stack pointer) is decremented to make room for local variables (

818:	528000a0 	mov	w0, #0x5        // w0 = 5
81c:	b9000fe0 	str	w0, [sp, #12]   // store at offset +12 (a)

828:	b9400fe1 	ldr	w1, [sp, #12]   // load a → w1
82c:	b9400be0 	ldr	w0, [sp, #8]    // load b → w0
830:	4b000020 	sub	w0, w1, w0      // w0 = a - b
834:	b90007e0 	str	w0, [sp, #4]    // store result (c) at [sp + 4]

838:	d503201f 	nop              // no-op (could be alignment or placeholder)
83c:	910043ff 	add	sp, sp, #0x10  // restore original stack pointer
840:	d65f03c0 	ret              // return from MAIN__
Stack pointer is restored to original value.
, which sets up the environment and invokes the Fortran
to point to the current stack frame.

84c:	b9001fe0 	str	w0, [sp, #28]    // argc
850:	f9000be1 	str	x1, [sp, #16]    // argv
Store command-line arguments to local stack for runtime use.

854:	f9400be1 	ldr	x1, [sp, #16]     // load argv
858:	b9401fe0 	ldr	w0, [sp, #28]     // load argc
85c:	97ffffa5 	bl	6f0 <_gfortran_set_args@plt>
to initialize argument parsing for Fortran.

860:	90000000 	adrp	x0, 0 <_init-0x660>     // load page base address
864:	91248001 	add	x1, x0, #0x920           // offset address into .rodata or similar
868:	528000e0 	mov	w0, #0x7                 // set options flag
86c:	97ffff9d 	bl	6e0 <_gfortran_set_options@plt>
Configures I/O formatting, IEEE flags, etc., via
Call the actual Fortran logic for subtraction.

874:	52800000 	mov	w0, #0x0         // return 0 (success)
878:	a8c27bfd 	ldp	x29, x30, [sp], #32
87c:	d65f03c0 	ret
This disassembly is from a Fortran program that performs:
All variables are stored on the stack and the arithmetic is performed using 32-bit registers (
). The actual program does not output anything—it just computes and stores the result.
Let me know if you want the binary layout, memory diagram, or the C equivalent.

This disassembly is in ARM64 (AArch64) assembly language, which is the 64-bit instruction set used by ARM processors (e.g., in modern Apple Silicon, some mobile devices, and servers). It appears to be the machine code output from a compiled Fortran program, as indicated by the function names (
is a common Fortran compiler-generated name for the user-defined main body) and calls to GNU Fortran (gfortran) runtime functions like
. These are part of the Fortran runtime library, suggesting this binary was compiled from a simple Fortran source code.
The disassembly has two main parts:

(likely the Fortran program’s core logic): A subroutine that allocates stack space, initializes two integer variables to 5 and 3, subtracts their difference (5 - 3 = 2), stores the result, and returns without further action (e.g., no output or side effects visible here).
(the C-style entry point): The program’s entry point, which sets up the stack, passes command-line arguments to the Fortran runtime, configures runtime options, calls

This code does not perform any input/output or complex operations—it’s essentially a “hello world”-level computation that computes but discards a result. In a real Fortran context, it might be a minimal example or part of a larger program where the result could be used elsewhere, but here it’s standalone and returns without printing.
I’ll explain each instruction in detail, including:
: What it does to registers, memory, or control flow.
: How it fits into the function and overall program.
: The hex bytes (as given) for reference.
I’ll group related instructions for clarity and note ARM64 conventions:
w0`) access the lower 32 bits (for ints).
Addresses are absolute but may be rebased in the binary.

children.label: Detailed Explanation of MAIN__ (Fortran Program Logic)

children.value: This function allocates 16 bytes on the stack for local variables (likely three 4-byte integers), performs a subtraction, and cleans up. It corresponds to Fortran code like:

INTEGER :: var1 = 5
INTEGER :: var2 = 3
INTEGER :: result
result = var1 - var2  ! Computes 2, but does nothing with it
is likely compiler-inserted for alignment or optimization.
(16 in decimal) from the stack pointer (
), effectively allocating 16 bytes of stack space for local storage. The result is written back to
. In ARM64, stack allocation is manual; this creates a small frame for variables (sp+4, sp+8, sp+12) and possibly alignment (stacks must be 16-byte aligned).
: Standard function prologue. The 16-byte size is minimal; 12 bytes for three 32-bit ints, padded to 16 for alignment. After this,
points to the new stack frame base.
in some notations, but as given).
(0x5) into the lower 32 bits of register
for 32-bit view). The upper 32 bits of
are implicitly zeroed. This is a “move immediate” instruction.
: Initializes a temporary register with the constant 5, which will be stored as the first variable (
: Writes to the stack location reserved for the first variable. Stack offsets are relative to current
: Saves the value 5 to a local variable (e.g.,
: Initializes temporary for the second variable (
: Saves the value 3 to the second stack location (e.g.,
: Loads the 32-bit value from memory at
. This is integer subtraction without carry (no overflow check visible).   **Context**: The core operation:
. In Fortran, integers are typically 32-bit, matching
: Saves the result to the third stack location (e.g.,
). Note: The result is stored but never used or returned—typical of a computation without side effects.

: No operation—does nothing, just a placeholder that advances the program counter. Often inserted by compilers for instruction alignment (ARM64 prefers 4-byte alignment) or to pad for timing/branch targets.
: Likely compiler-generated; no functional purpose here. In some cases, it’s for debugging or to avoid hazards, but unnecessary in this simple sequence.
, deallocating the stack frame and restoring the caller’s stack.
: Function epilogue—cleans up locals before returning.
: Returns to the caller by jumping to the address in the link register
). No return value is set, so it implicitly returns whatever is in
(undefined here, but Fortran subroutines don’t return values like this).

children.label: Detailed Explanation of main (Program Entry Point)

children.value: This is the standard wrapper for Fortran programs compiled with gfortran. It handles C-style
, initializes the Fortran runtime, calls the Fortran main body (
), and exits. Corresponds to the implicit “program” wrapper in Fortran.
: Prologue: Saves caller’s frame pointer and return address, allocates 32 bytes (for locals like argc/argv and alignment).
for easy access to locals (e.g., [x29, #28] for offsets).
: Standard ABI for frame pointer setup.
(argc, the argument count from OS) at
: Prepares argv as second argument for the upcoming runtime call.
), which is a relative jump (signed 26-bit offset). Sets
to return address. This calls the Fortran runtime to process command-line args for Fortran use.
: Initializes Fortran’s argument handling. PLT is Procedure Linkage Table for dynamic linking.
: “Address relative to page”: Loads the base address of the current 4GB page (0 here, likely the data section) into
: Prepares a base address for the next instruction to compute an address.
. This computes the address of some global data (likely an options table for Fortran).
now points to a constant array or structure for runtime configuration.
: Argument for the options call, perhaps the number of options or a flags value (specific to gfortran).
: Configures Fortran runtime options, e.g., error handling, floating-point behavior, etc. The values are compiler defaults.
: Prepares program exit status for the OS.
(post-index). Restores frame pointer, link register, and deallocates stack.
: Returns to OS or caller), with exit code 0 in
If run, the program does nothing visible—no print, just exits. To confirm or debug, you’d use tools like gdb or compile with
for source mapping. This is typical unoptimized code; optimization might inline or remove the computation.
